text: Hi guys, we are proud to reveal <http://nodes.io> - a new way to create with code. We have been working together with <@UEG9ECNSU> on Nodes at Variable (<http://variable.io>) since 2017. We use it to create interactive installations, visualise data, experiment with generative algorithms, build custom design tools and more. We are currently looking for feedback here, or drop us a line at <mailto:hello@nodes.io|hello@nodes.io> if you want to know more. You can read more about the underlying tech and our journey at <http://nodes.io/story/>

text: There is no easy way to share it publicly yet as quite a bit of setup is required. We have some ideas on what’s next but we want to make that decision based on initial response. How do you see yourself using it?

Would love to hear your feedback: <https://medium.com/software-engineering-problems/out-of-the-tar-pit-another-approach-b3e701e089ee>

text:
Excited to see this! This is very close to something that I've been working on in my spare time. I'd be very curious to hear how this handles interactive input, as well as how it handles infinite timelines (ie. how do you use the time node under the hood).

Is it like dataflow (rerender all dependent nodes when you change the inputs), or something else?

elements.text:
Excited to see this! This is very close to something that I've been working on in my spare time. I'd be very curious to hear how this handles interactive input, as well as how it handles infinite timelines (ie. how do you use the time node under the hood).

Is it like dataflow (rerender all dependent nodes when you change the inputs), or something else?

text: And additionally I'd be very excited to play around with it whenever you're able to share something. :slightly_smiling_face: I'm a firm believer that the Houdini style of node editing is incredibly powerful.

text: I added Nodes to my codex (<https://github.com/ivanreese/visual-programming-codex>). Upon doing so, I realized that you guys... are like a band from 2009 (eg: Grizzly Bear, Panda Bear, Ponytail, Pens, Braids, Chairs, Cousins, Cub, and of course.. Free Nude Celebs) in your love of totally un-Google-able names (eg: Nodes, Variable). Kudos.

text: We have worked with Quartz Composer for some 2 years in our past design life. All animation you see here are generated with QC: <https://web.archive.org/web/20180512170452/http://prabros.com/design/projects/rethinking-chat-ui> The problem we found with the box and noodles stuff is that as you scale up, it becomes very unwieldily to handle the complexity of the spaghetti that gets formed. <@UEH5JQS0J> Have you found a solution to tame this?

attachments.title: Rethinking the Chat Interface
attachments.text: New interaction ideas for chat UI in mobile devices.

elements.text: We have worked with Quartz Composer for some 2 years in our past design life. All animation you see here are generated with QC:

Have you found a solution to tame this?

text: The <http://nodes.io|nodes.io> project has achieved a huge amount in just 2 years, and for that you are to be commended. However, the choice of JS as the user language is regrettable, because JS is one of the objectively hardest languages to program in, as it full of traps for the unwary.  I realize that given your ambitious goals and short time window it wasn't possible to consider a different language, but writing and debugging JS is not an easy thing.

elements.text: The
nodes.io

project has achieved a huge amount in just 2 years, and for that you are to be commended. However, the choice of JS as the user language is regrettable, because JS is one of the objectively hardest languages to program in, as it full of traps for the unwary.  I realize that given your ambitious goals and short time window it wasn't possible to consider a different language, but writing and debugging JS is not an easy thing.

text: I also find JS lacking. I don't like how function dispatch works — it's generally too static, too strict. So I wrote my own JS module system that does function dispatch entirely with string names, and soft-fails silently, so I can be a little more dynamic than JS normally allows. It's very, very good. :wink:

elements.text: I also find JS lacking. I don't like how function dispatch works — it's generally too static, too strict. So I wrote my own JS module system that does function dispatch entirely with string names, and soft-fails silently, so I can be a little more dynamic than JS normally allows. It's very, very good.

text:
As for nodes, I think the choice of JS is perfect — you're sitting on top of the web platform, and JS is the lingua franca of the web. If someone wants to write in a transpiled language, the "we speak npm" approach to integration should work pretty nicely (albeit missing a bit of liveness, perhaps).

Whereas if they chose any other language, they'd still be generating JS code at the end of the day, but forcing people to understand a bigger surface area — Nodes, the web stack, JS, plus whatever language they chose.

elements.text:
As for nodes, I think the choice of JS is perfect — you're sitting on top of the web platform, and JS is the lingua franca of the web. If someone wants to write in a transpiled language, the "we speak npm" approach to integration should work pretty nicely (albeit missing a bit of liveness, perhaps).

Whereas if they chose any other language, they'd still be generating JS code at the end of the day, but forcing people to understand a bigger surface area — Nodes, the web stack, JS, plus whatever language they chose.

text: never confuse popularity with merit. COBOL was the #1 language for decades and it was really crappy. Java is the COBOL of our time and similarly lousy. The fact that web browser companies agreed upon JS as the main language doomed the world to billions of lines of flaky code, and gigantic web pages that even today's supercomputers struggle to render quickly. IMHO any next generation system that dumps you back 25 years into JS is not of the future, but something with one foot planted firmly in the past.

elements.text: never confuse popularity with merit. COBOL was the #1 language for decades and it was really crappy. Java is the COBOL of our time and similarly lousy. The fact that web browser companies agreed upon JS as the main language doomed the world to billions of lines of flaky code, and gigantic web pages that even today's supercomputers struggle to render quickly. IMHO any next generation system that dumps you back 25 years into JS is not of the future, but something with one foot planted firmly in the past.

text: JS isn't the language they chose for Nodes. They chose the web platform. JS just happens to be the language you need to sit atop if you're going to target the web. ClojureScript and PureScript and Elm and whatever other "better" web language might be an option for them... still needs to sit atop JS. Even something targeting WASM still needs to speak JS. They could hide the JS from the user of Nodes, but why? That doesn't fit at all with their stated goals.

elements.text: JS isn't the language they chose for Nodes. They chose the web platform. JS just happens to be the language you need to sit atop if you're going to target the web. They could hide the JS from the user of Nodes, but why? That doesn't fit at all with their stated goals.

text: Also, your critique isn't a critique of Nodes so much as a critique of the web platform. I don't think this is the thread for that conversation. I'd be happy to meet you in <#C5T9GPWFL|thinking-together> for that.

text:
There was never a moment of choice. JS is our everyday language ever since I started variable in 2012. After years of Java/Processing and C++/OpenGL the speed of iteration that WebGL gave me in 2010 (<http://marcinignac.com/projects/nine-point-five/>) made me never look back. Tools like <http://www.plask.org> and later Electron only accelerated that by covering “desktop app” use cases.

So when we started Nodes it was very much extension of the whole baggage of libraries for data viz (d3.js), 3d graphics (pex) and functional programming / data processing (ramda, <http://thi.ng/umbrella|thi.ng/umbrella>) we already used. They all still work in Nodes, something you can’t say about other attempts that tried to reinvent the thing from scratch.

That comes with downsides of course, like the mentioned debugging. Some things like the cable soup problem we managed to mitigate e.g. with react/redux style of state management mixed with more port-to-port data flow. We are planning on writing separate articles on that journey.

text:
I've posted my project before, but there's been enough progress in the last few months that I thought I'd bump it one more time: <https://github.com/akkartik/mu/blob/master/subx/Readme.md>

Yeah, my answer for the Future of Programming starts with a new syntax for Assembly. How the heck did that happen? I certainly didn't plan it to go this way. I've never tried to write out the reason before, and it got too long for Slack, so here's a link to the comment I wrote: <http://akkartik.name/post/this-tree-im-on>
